content: Our daughter is in her 2nd week of Basic Training for Army National Guard and had to have surgery today for an abscess. Now they are talking about medically discharging her on the grounds that she may have Crohn's Disease. If she is discharged will she retain any type of benefits? Will she only be paid for the 2 weeks or will she still qualify for her sign-on bonus?

content: most likely no benefits, unless service connected, which it appears in this case not to be, but she will be paid for her time.... and benefits in the Guard or reserves is only while on active status, ie, drilling, 2 week anual training or activation... I was in reserves for 18 years and I had no military benefits except for those times.... Crohn's I believe is treatable so I do not see where your daughter could not continue with a reserve/guard obligation but I suspect that she will have to have treatment first and then doctors memo stating to the effect that she can participate.... good luck. But there are more informed individuals then I on these forums. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE

content: If you are able to communicate with her, tell her to ask about medical coverage. She may not rate any military medical coverage, but she should ask, and if nothing else, she should ask about getting the transitional health coverage. This is NOT FREE, but if she enrolls, she won't run into being UNINSURABLE due to pre-existing conditions. If she can get transitional medical insurance, someone in the family should help her pay for it or pay for it until she gets a job or gets insurance through her college or university. Careful with that "pre-existing" clause, it trips up a lot of people.

content: She will get what is called an "Entry Level Separation". Basically, that means she will get no benefits other than the cost of the flight back home. When you get an entry level sep, it is as if you were never in the military. Like it never happened. Also, since she didn't meet the obligations of her bonus contract (usually completion of basic training or completion of MOS training), she will not receive her bonus. But, she will not have to pay back the basic pay that she received for those two weeks.

content: My fiance was medically retired from the Corps because he has chron's. He is not deployable because the condition, while treatable, requires him to be on a strict diet and recieve medicine he cannot administer to himself. He too had an absess (sp?), nut he got his while in Iraq. The chron's caused him to lose about 60 pounds and the meals that were available in Iraq were not able to give him sufficient nutrients since he couldn't eat a lot of the sides, just the meats. Anyways, my point is, it's very hard to stay in with chron's (even if you've served 13 honorable years like my fiance), the military tries not to retain nondeployable members.
